text: I grew up with a younger sibling with autism, and I deeply love and care for her. As I grew up, my parents always told me that I had to be successful so I could care for her when they died. I was perfectly okay with this at first, but as I entered grade 7 I started thinking life and my reasons for living.
modified_text: I grew up with a younger sibling with autism, and I deeply love and care for her. As I grew up, my parents always told me that I had to be successful so I could care for her when they died. I was perfectly okay with this at first, but as I entered grade 7 I started thinking life and my reasons for living. I grew up with a younger sibling with autism, and I deeply love and care for her. As I grew up, my parents always told me that I had to be successful so I could care for her when they died. I was perfectly okay with this at first, but as I entered grade 7 I started thinking life and my reasons for living. **I began to believe that all my future choices were solely determined by this responsibility, feeling like every decision had to revolve around taking care of her. This made me think that everything in my life, from friendships to career choices, would forever be overshadowed by this one obligation, even though it wasn't always the case.**

In principle I have changed since that time: more time with family, treat the third child as my own (even maybe slightly more). The lover told the truth to his family and is now divorced. Since she became a part of our family, I can't shake the feeling that her decisions and actions are somehow linked to me. I find myself overanalyzing every detail, wondering if her presence is causing ripples in our dynamics. It's like her choices hold a mirror up to my own life, making me question everything in a way I never did before.

text: When I was little, my sister, who was my best friend, would do things like start a club with her imaginary friend and exclude me from it. When we were older, at our church, there were plenty of people her age to hang out with. Since I had hung out with her my whole life, I was used to this age of person and I wanted to be friends with them, too. My sister had outgrown me, so she wanted to have these friends to herself. A new convert came into our church that was my age, but she was allowed to hang out with these older friends because they wanted her to have friends since she was new. Again I was excluded. Today, I feel these same feelings as I deal with people in life. As soon as I feel a little bit rejected (which I probably magnify) I exclude myself and then feel jealous and bitter toward them. How do I get over these childhood events so that it will not affect my relationships with people around me? Thank you!

text: I found out that Iam pregnant 2 weeks ago. Iam not ready to have a baby at this point in time, but itas still something thatas heartbreaking and difficult to bear emotionally. He later said that he overreacted and should have considered my feelings more. My guard went up because I felt that his support was conditional upon whether I chose to abort or not, and still do. I keep thinking about how others have partners who are more empathetic and committed, no matter the circumstances. It makes me question if my partner's reaction is justifiable, or if I deserve better support in such a challenging time.
